Column Comment.0: SAMPLE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample used in technical analysis.
Column Comment.1: DESCRIPTION IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the description of this sample.
Column Comment.2: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.3: AVERAGE RATIO VALUE: the average value of the ratio, or the value of a singlereading if only one reading is provided.
Column Comment.4: DESCRIPTION VALUE: The numeric value associated with the description type. Usethis column when the value given is the average of several values, or if only a singlevalue is provided.
Column Comment.7: CALCULATION METHOD IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the method or formulaused to create a calculated or derived value.
Column Comment.8: COST: A value associated with the cost of a specification, such as annual operatingcost.
Column Comment.9: CURRENCY CONVERSION: A number which, when multiplied by the stored value,will re-create the original value in the original currency used.
Column Comment.10: CURRENCY ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE: The units of measure in which thecurrency was originally received.
Column Comment.12: DATE FORMAT DESCRIPTION: Use this column to define the level of precision inthe DATE format columns, such as YYYY, or YYYQQ, or YYYYMM or YYYYMMDD
Column Comment.13: DESCRIPTION: Textual description of the characteristic.
Column Comment.14: DESCRIPTION CODE: a descriptive code allowed for a sample description. Forexample, this table may be used to store miscelaneous data types that are obtainedfrom proprietary lab analysis.
Column Comment.15: DESCRIPTION TYPE: the type of description for the sample.
Column Comment.16: EFFECTIVE DATE: date on which the data in this row came into effect.
Column Comment.17: EXPIRY DATE: Date on which the data in this row of data was no longer in effect.
Column Comment.18: MAXIMUM DATE: the maximum date that this description covers, used in caseswhere the value was created over an extended period of time (such as aging asample of oil by exposing it to the air for several days)
Column Comment.19: MAXIMUM RATIO VALUE: The maximum value allowed for this ratio between thesetwo samples.
Column Comment.20: MAXIMUM VALUE: the maximum value for a specification, such as the maximumdiameter of a tank, or the maximum load capacity of a vehicle.
Column Comment.23: MINIMUM DATE: the minimum date that this description covers, used in cases wherethe value was created over an extended period of time (such as aging a sample of oilby exposing it to the air for several days)
Column Comment.24: MINIMUM RATIO VALUE: The minimum value allowed for this ratio between thesetwo samples.
Column Comment.25: MINIMUM VALUE: the minimum value associated with a specification, such asminimum pipe thickness or minimum pressure capability.
Column Comment.28: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.29: REFERENCE VALUE: the value of a reference point. For example, where theequipment is a tank for which tank strappings are measured, the reference pointwould be the height measurement in the tank. The volume measure at the referencetank strapping will usually be captured in AVERAGE VALUE. Other reference values,such as pressures or temperatures that reference specifications are also permitted.
Column Comment.31: EQUIPMENT SPECIFICATION REFERENCE TYPE: Use this table to indicate thekind of reference point used to describe specifications. For example, if thespecifications being captured are tank strappings, the SPEC TYPE = TANKSTRAPPING and SPECREF TYPE = STRAPPING MARKERS and theREFERENCED VALUE = the height measure on the tank.
Column Comment.33: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.34: REPORTED RATIO: In order to maintain data integrity this column is used to inputraw data such as fractions. This will help to clarify any variations or loss of precisionfound in the AVERAGE_RATIO_VALUE column which will only have the numbersthe ratio is related to- to a certain decimal place. Note: Special care should be takento maintain consistency throughout the column and this column should not be used inthe place of AVERAGE_RATIO_VALUE but as a reference for that table.
Column Comment.36: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.37: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.38: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.39: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.40: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.41: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.42: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.43: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
